text.p: The following are the main stories from Tuesday morning's German newspapers:
FRANKFURTER ALLGEMEINE ZEITUNG
- The SPD makes pitch for youths, large majority at party congress backs proposal to slap a training levy on employers. Party also urges cutting minimum voting age to 16 from 18.
- Truck drivers block border crossings into France.
- Joy surrounds lira's return to EMS. But banks warn it is not an early preliminary decision for currency union.
- Consumer prices in west Germany declined 0.1 percent in November from October and were up 1.4 percent from a year earlier.
- Hans-Olaf Henkel remains president of BDI German industry federation
- Difficult negotiations for metalworkers in North Rhine-Westphalia. Employers want an agreement with steady costs.
- CDU wants big tax reform at start of 1999. FDP wants earlier start.
HANDELSBLATT
- CDU to raise pressure on the SPD in the debate over the 1997 tax law, says CDU general secretary Peter Hintze. CDU will not coproise on taxes.
- SPD party conference agrees on training levy for employers.
- Talk about taxes has cut into consumer spending of many Germans.
SUEDDEUTSCHE ZEITUNG
- SPD wants to make up lost ground with youth.
- Europe welcomes return of lira to EMS.
- Another new record on German bourses. DAX rises 1.3 percent to 2,799
DIE WELT
- SPD wants training levy on employers.
- Truck drivers strike in France expands
- Not enough fuel to fly: Foreign airlines to be controlled more closely in Germany.
-- Bonn Newsroom +49 228 26097160
